conflicts_of_interest.name: Conflicts of Interest
conflicts_of_interest.description: Opinions addressing when public officials must disqualify themselves from governmental decisions due to personal financial interests, under the Political Reform Act (Government Code 87100 et seq.), Government Code Section 1090, and common law doctrines.

issues.name: Business Entity Interest
issues.description: Whether a public official must disqualify from a decision that could financially affect a business entity in which the official has an investment, holds a position as director or officer, or is otherwise financially connected. Under Section 87103(a), an official has a disqualifying interest if the decision could foreseeably have a material financial effect on a business entity in which they have a $2,000 or more investment or serve as a director, officer, partner, trustee, or manager.

issues.name: Real Property Proximity
issues.description: Whether a public official must disqualify from a decision that could affect real property in which the official has a financial interest, typically based on the proximity of the official's property to the subject of the governmental decision. Under Section 87103(b) and Regulation 18702.2, the analysis considers whether the official's real property is within a specified distance (often 500 feet) of the property subject to the decision and whether the decision could have a reasonably foreseeable material financial effect.

issues.name: Source of Income
issues.description: Whether a public official must disqualify from a decision that could affect a source of income to the official. Under Section 87103(c), a source of income is any person or entity that has provided income of $500 or more within 12 months prior to the decision. The analysis examines whether the decision could foreseeably have a material financial effect on the official's source of income, including employers, clients, and business partners.

issues.name: Gift Source Disqualification
issues.description: Whether a public official must disqualify from a decision that could affect a person who has given the official a reportable gift. Under Section 87103(d), an official has a disqualifying interest if the decision could foreseeably have a material financial effect on a person who has provided gifts to the official aggregating $250 or more within 12 months prior to the decision. This provision aims to prevent donors from gaining influence over official decisions through gifts.

issues.name: Personal Financial Effect
issues.description: Whether a governmental decision would have a reasonably foreseeable material financial effect on the official's personal finances, distinct from their interests in specific business entities, real property, or income sources. Section 87103(e) serves as a catch-all provision covering financial effects on the official's personal expenses, income, assets, or liabilities that do not fit neatly into the other categories of economic interest.

issues.name: Section 1090 Self-Dealing
issues.description: Whether a public officer or employee is financially interested in a contract made by the board or body of which they are a member, in violation of Government Code Section 1090. Unlike the Political Reform Act's disqualification approach, Section 1090 prohibits the entire governing body from entering into the contract if any single member has a financial interest, making the contract void ab initio. Section 1097 provides criminal penalties for violations.

issues.name: Post-Employment Restrictions
issues.description: What restrictions apply to former public officials who leave government service and seek to represent private interests before their former agency. Sections 87400-87407 impose a one-year ban on former officials appearing before or communicating with their former agency for compensation on matters they previously participated in, and a permanent ban on switching sides on proceedings they were personally involved in.

issues.name: Public Generally Exception
issues.description: Whether an official's financial interest in a governmental decision is indistinguishable from the effect on the public generally, thereby exempting the official from disqualification. Under Regulation 18703, if a decision financially affects a significant segment of the public and the effect on the official's interest is not unique compared to the effect on the broader segment, the official may participate despite having a financial interest.

issues.name: Legally Required Participation
issues.description: Whether an official who has a disqualifying conflict of interest may nonetheless participate in a decision under the rule of necessity, because no alternative decision-maker is available. Regulation 18707 provides that if an official's disqualification would prevent a body from taking action on an item, and the official's participation is legally required, the conflicted official may participate despite the conflict.

issues.name: Remote and Noninterest Exceptions
issues.description: Whether an official's financial interest in a contract falls within one of the statutory exceptions to Section 1090's prohibition on self-dealing. Sections 1091 and 1091.5 enumerate specific categories of "remote" and "noninterest" exceptions, such as being a nonsalaried board member of a nonprofit, holding a minor ownership stake, or being a landlord or tenant of the contracting party, that allow the contract to proceed if the interest is disclosed and the official abstains from voting.

issues.name: Spousal and Community Property Interests
issues.description: Whether a public official must disqualify from a decision based on the financial interests of the official's spouse or registered domestic partner. Under California community property law, a spouse's financial interests are attributed to the official, including business entity investments, sources of income, and real property held as community property. This creates disqualifying conflicts even when the official personally has no direct interest in the matter.

issues.name: Common Law Conflict of Interest
issues.description: Whether common law doctrines of conflict of interest, independent of the Political Reform Act and Government Code Section 1090, apply to prohibit an official's participation. Common law conflicts arise from incompatible offices, fiduciary duties, or situations where an official's personal interests compromise their duty of loyalty to the public, even when statutory conflict provisions may not directly apply.

campaign_finance.name: Campaign Finance
campaign_finance.description: Opinions addressing the regulation of political contributions, expenditures, and campaign committee activities under the Political Reform Act (Government Code 82000 et seq.), including contribution definitions and limits, reporting requirements, independent expenditures, and the permissible use of campaign funds.

issues.name: Contribution Definition and Political Purpose
issues.description: Whether a payment, in-kind service, or other benefit constitutes a "contribution" under Section 82015 of the Political Reform Act. Opinions address when payments are made for "political purposes," the distinction between contributions and non-political payments, and exceptions under Regulation 18215(c) for communications that do not contain express advocacy or references to candidacy.

issues.name: Use of Campaign Funds and Personal Use Restrictions
issues.description: Whether specific expenditures of campaign funds comply with the trust provision of Section 85202(b) and the personal use restrictions of Sections 85800-85806. Opinions analyze whether expenditures are "reasonably related" or "directly related" to a political, legislative, or governmental purpose, including contributions to ballot measures, conference sponsorship, and attendance at political events.

issues.name: Mass Mailing at Public Expense
issues.description: Whether communications featuring elected officers constitute prohibited mass mailings under Sections 89001 and 89002 of the Act. Opinions address the definition of "mass mailing" (200+ substantially similar items in a calendar month), the meaning of "features an elected officer," the public moneys requirement, and the application of these restrictions to newsletters, social media, and electronic communications.

issues.name: Section 84308 Pay-to-Play Disqualification
issues.description: Whether contributions to officers on appointive bodies trigger disqualification from proceedings involving the contributor under Section 84308. Opinions address the scope of disqualification, which officers and proceedings are covered, whether subcontractors and indirect beneficiaries are subject to the provision, and how the 12-month look-back period applies.

issues.name: Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Requirements
issues.description: How candidates, committees, and other filers must report contributions, expenditures, and loans on campaign statements under Sections 84200-84216. Opinions address filing locations and deadlines, the interaction between state and local filing requirements under Section 81009.5, reporting of loan terms and nonmonetary contributions, committee formation thresholds under Section 82013, and the preemption of local ordinances.

issues.name: Contribution Limits and Inter-Candidate Transfers
issues.description: Whether contributions comply with applicable limits under Sections 85301-85303 and whether transfers of campaign funds between candidates or committees are permissible under Section 85304. Opinions address the prohibition on inter-candidate transfers, affiliated entity contribution aggregation under Regulation 18531.1, slate mailer organization requirements under Sections 84305-84305.5, and the interaction between contribution limits and independent expenditures.

issues.name: Independent Expenditures and Coordination
issues.description: Whether expenditures qualify as "independent expenditures" under Section 82031 or are instead coordinated expenditures treated as contributions. Opinions analyze the coordination standard under Section 85500(d), the distinction between independent and behested expenditures, the ability of candidate-controlled committees to make independent expenditures for other candidates, and affiliated committee restrictions.

issues.name: Member Communications Exception
issues.description: Whether communications from membership organizations to their members qualify for the member communications exception under Section 85312 and are therefore not treated as contributions or expenditures. Opinions address what constitutes a bona fide membership organization, the scope of permissible member communications, how local ordinance contribution limits interact with the state Act's member communications exception, and political party committee communications.

issues.name: Behested Payment Reporting
issues.description: Whether payments made at the behest of elected officers must be reported under Section 84224 as behested payments. Opinions address the definition of "made at the behest of" under Section 82041.3, the distinction between behested payments and contributions, the safe harbor for charitable solicitations that do not "feature" an elected officer under Regulation 18215.3(b), and the $5,000 aggregate reporting threshold.

issues.name: Committee Formation and Management
issues.description: Requirements for forming, managing, and operating campaign committees under the Act, including the $1,000 committee formation threshold under Section 82013, bank account requirements under Section 85201, committee designation and redesignation, the distinction between primarily formed and general purpose committees, and slate mailer organization registration and disclosure obligations.

gifts_honoraria.name: Gifts and Honoraria
gifts_honoraria.description: Opinions addressing the limitations on gifts and honoraria that public officials may accept under the Political Reform Act (Government Code 89500 et seq.), including gift valuation, the honoraria ban, travel payment exceptions, and the permissible use of campaign funds for personal benefit.

issues.name: Honoraria Ban and Exceptions
issues.description: Whether a payment to a public official for a speech, published article, or attendance at a gathering constitutes a prohibited honorarium, and whether exceptions apply. Under Sections 89501 and 89502, elected officials and designated employees are prohibited from accepting honoraria, but Section 89501(b) excludes earned income for personal services customarily provided in connection with a bona fide business, trade, or profession (such as teaching or practicing law), unless speechmaking is the predominant activity of that business as determined under Regulations 18932 through 18932.3.

issues.name: Gift Limits and Applicability
issues.description: Whether the Act's annual per-source gift limit applies to a particular public official, and how gifts must be reported on the Statement of Economic Interests. Under Section 89503, specified state and local officials are prohibited from accepting gifts from a single source exceeding a biennial adjusted dollar limit in a calendar year, though certain officials such as non-elected part-time members of governing boards of public higher education institutions are exempt under Section 89503(d). Officials subject to the gift limit must also disclose gifts of $50 or more from a single source on their Form 700.

issues.name: Gift Definition and Valuation
issues.description: Whether a particular payment, benefit, or item of value constitutes a reportable gift under the Act, and how to properly value it for disclosure and gift-limit purposes. Under Section 82028, a gift is any payment that confers a personal benefit on the recipient to the extent consideration of equal or greater value is not received; Regulation 18942 excludes certain items such as informational materials from the gift definition, while Regulation 18946.2 establishes valuation rules for invitation-only events based on pro-rata cost allocation.

issues.name: Travel Payment Exceptions
issues.description: Whether payments for an official's travel, lodging, and subsistence are exempt from the Act's gift limits under the travel exception, and how to distinguish exempt travel costs from non-exempt activities such as tours and entertainment. Under Section 89506(a), payments for actual transportation and related lodging and subsistence that are reasonably related to a legislative or governmental purpose are not subject to the gift limit if provided by a government, educational institution, or 501(c)(3) nonprofit, though such payments remain reportable gifts that may trigger conflict-of-interest disqualification.

issues.name: Campaign Fund Personal Use
issues.description: Whether a particular expenditure of campaign funds or surplus campaign funds complies with the Act's personal use restrictions, including donations to nonprofits, payment for education or conferences, legal defense costs, and candidate self-compensation. Under Sections 89510 through 89519, campaign fund expenditures must be reasonably related to a political, legislative, or governmental purpose, and expenditures conferring a substantial personal benefit must be directly related to such a purpose; surplus campaign funds after leaving office or losing an election are further restricted to enumerated uses including charitable donations under Section 89519.

lobbying.name: Lobbying
lobbying.description: Opinions addressing the regulation of lobbying activity under the Political Reform Act (Government Code 86100 et seq.), including lobbyist registration requirements, disclosure and reporting obligations, gift restrictions specific to lobbyists, and prohibitions on certain lobbyist conduct.

issues.name: Lobbyist Registration and Certification
issues.description: Whether a person or entity must register as a lobbyist, lobbying firm, or lobbyist employer with the Secretary of State, and what procedural requirements apply to registration, renewal, amendment, termination, and ethics certification. Under Sections 86100-86107, individual lobbyists must file certifications (including completion of an ethics course per Section 86103(d)), lobbying firms and lobbyist employers must register within ten days of qualifying, and registrations must be renewed biennially. Section 86300 exempts state employees acting within the scope of employment and certain media entities from these requirements, though the exemption for outside consultants depends on whether they are designated in the agency's conflict of interest code.

issues.name: Lobbying Disclosure and Reporting
issues.description: What payments and expenditures lobbyist employers, lobbying firms, and $5,000 filers must disclose on their periodic reports, including payments to lobbying firms, compensation to in-house lobbyists, activity expenses, and other payments to influence legislative or administrative action. Under Sections 86115-86116, lobbyist employers must file quarterly reports itemizing all payments connected with influencing legislative or administrative action, including overhead expenses and compensation to employees who spend 10 percent or more of their time on lobbying. Section 86116.5 imposes additional disclosure requirements on state and local agencies, including reporting of dues to organizations that spend significant amounts on lobbying.

issues.name: Lobbyist Gift Restrictions
issues.description: Whether a lobbyist or lobbying firm may provide a gift, payment, or other benefit to a state official, and whether such items fall within an exception to the $10 monthly gift limit. Under Section 86203, it is unlawful for a lobbyist or lobbying firm to make gifts aggregating more than $10 in a calendar month to any one person, or to act as an agent or intermediary in the making of any gift, or to arrange for the making of any gift by any other person. Section 86201 broadly defines the covered officials, and Section 86204 makes it unlawful for officials to accept gifts that violate these limits. Exceptions under Section 82028(b) include informational materials and personalized plaques or trophies worth less than $250.

issues.name: Lobbyist Conduct Prohibitions
issues.description: Whether a lobbyist's or lobbying firm's conduct violates the specific prohibitions on lobbyist behavior set forth in Section 86205, including the ban on contingency fee arrangements, creating personal obligations, deceiving officials about pending legislation, and representing the ability to control official action. Section 86205(f) prohibits any lobbyist or lobbying firm from accepting or agreeing to accept any payment contingent upon the defeat, enactment, or outcome of any proposed legislative or administrative action, with no exceptions to this ban. The scope of the prohibition depends on the statutory definition of 'administrative action' under Section 82002, which includes ratemaking and quasi-legislative proceedings but excludes proceedings to award grants or contracts.

other.name: Other
other.description: Opinions addressing miscellaneous provisions of the Political Reform Act not primarily falling within the conflicts of interest, campaign finance, gifts/honoraria, or lobbying categories, including mass mailing restrictions on public agencies, statement of economic interests filing requirements, jurisdiction and coverage questions, and enforcement and audit procedures.

issues.name: Mass Mailing at Public Expense
issues.description: Whether a newsletter, publication, or other communication sent by or on behalf of a government agency constitutes a prohibited mass mailing at public expense under the Act. Section 89001 prohibits sending newsletters or other mass mailings at public expense, and Regulation 18901 specifies that a mailing is prohibited only if it is delivered to a recipient's residence or business, features or references an elected officer affiliated with the sending agency, is paid for with public moneys, and involves more than 200 substantially similar items in a single calendar month. Opinions address exceptions for unsolicited requests, inter-agency mailings, items available for public pickup, newspaper inserts, and electronic communications.

issues.name: Permissible Use of Campaign Funds
issues.description: Whether a candidate, elected officer, or political committee may use campaign funds for a specific purpose under the Act's personal use restrictions. Under Sections 85800-85802, campaign fund expenditures must be at minimum reasonably related to a political, legislative, or governmental purpose, and expenditures conferring a substantial personal benefit of $100 or more must be directly related to such a purpose. Opinions address travel expenses, conference fees, charitable donations, PAC activities, surplus fund disposition, and the distinction between permissible political expenditures and prohibited personal use.

issues.name: Statements of Economic Interests and Conflict of Interest Codes
issues.description: Whether specific officials must file Statements of Economic Interests (Form 700), which positions must be designated in an agency's conflict of interest code, and questions about filing procedures and code reviewing bodies. Under Sections 87200-87210, specified elected and appointed officials must file Form 700 disclosing their economic interests, and under Section 87300, every state and local government agency must adopt a conflict of interest code designating positions that involve decision-making and specifying the financial interests those position holders must disclose. Opinions address which entities must adopt codes, which positions to designate, the appropriate code reviewing body, and procedural questions about filing and public access to filed statements.

issues.name: Jurisdiction and Agency Coverage Under the Act
issues.description: Whether a particular entity constitutes a 'local government agency' or 'agency' subject to the Political Reform Act, and whether specific individuals qualify as 'public officials' covered by the Act's provisions. Under Sections 82003 and 82041, the Act applies to state and local government agencies, with 'local government agency' defined to include counties, cities, districts, and other political subdivisions. The Commission applies a multi-factor test from In re Siegel to determine whether entities such as nonprofit corporations, joint powers authorities, or trade associations formed by public entities are themselves public agencies subject to the Act's disclosure, disqualification, and other requirements.

issues.name: Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Requirements
issues.description: Whether specific campaign contributions, expenditures, or committee activities trigger reporting and disclosure obligations under the Act, and how those obligations must be fulfilled. Under Sections 84100-84615, candidates, committees, and other political entities must file periodic campaign statements disclosing contributions received and expenditures made, with specific rules governing electronic filing, signature requirements, contribution aggregation, committee formation thresholds, mandatory audits, and record retention. Opinions address filing procedures, the definition of 'candidate' and 'committee,' contribution limits and aggregation rules, and the obligations of filing officers.

issues.name: Lobbying Registration, Reporting, and Restrictions
issues.description: Whether specific activities constitute 'lobbying' requiring registration and reporting under the Act, and what obligations apply to registered lobbyists and their employers. Under Sections 86100-86116, individuals who receive compensation to communicate with legislative or administrative officials to influence legislative or administrative action must register as lobbyists and comply with reporting requirements, gift limits, and contribution restrictions. Opinions address the scope of 'administrative action' including ratemaking proceedings, the allocation of lobbying time for dual-role employees, membership dues used for lobbying, and the activities that trigger registration and reporting by lobbyist employers.
